title: Cauda Equina Syndrome
icd10: G95.89 (Other specified diseases of spinal cord)
scope: ** Emergency evaluation and management of cauda equina syndrome in adults. Covers urgent recognition of incomplete vs. complete CES, emergent MRI, surgical decompression timing, etiologic workup (disc herniation, tumor, abscess, hematoma), bladder management, and functional prognostication. Excludes conus medullaris syndrome (partially overlaps — key distinguishing features addressed), malignant epidural spinal cord compression above the conus (separate template), and chronic lumbar stenosis without CES features.

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Infection (epidural abscess); baseline for surgery; leukocytosis; anemia assessment
Essential/Core Labs.target: Normal; leukocytosis → consider abscess; thrombocytopenia affects surgical candidacy

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Electrolytes; renal function (contrast, NSAIDs); glucose; hepatic function (anesthetic risk)
Coagulopathy; anticoagulation status; surgical clearance; epidural hematoma etiology
Essential/Core Labs.target: Normal; INR <1.5 for surgery; prolonged → consider epidural hematoma

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Epidural abscess differential (ESR >20 mm/hr: 94% sensitivity for spinal abscess); discitis; malignancy
Essential/Core Labs.target: Normal; markedly elevated (ESR >30-50, CRP >10) → strongly consider abscess or infection

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Epidural abscess; bacteremia; source identification if infectious etiology suspected
Essential/Core Labs.target: Negative; positive → epidural abscess or hematogenous source

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Baseline; anesthetic risk; diabetic patients at increased disc herniation and infection risk
Surgical candidacy; blood product availability for emergency decompression
UTI (common comorbidity and mimicker of urinary symptoms); neurogenic bladder assessment; baseline
Essential/Core Labs.target: Normal; UTI may coexist — treat but do NOT attribute bladder dysfunction solely to UTI if CES features present

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: MRI and anesthetic planning; pregnancy may exacerbate disc herniation (increased lordosis/weight)
Essential/Core Labs.target: Negative; if positive → MRI still indicated (no gadolinium needed for CES diagnosis)

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Bacterial infection differential (more specific than CRP); if abscess suspected

Extended Workup.rationale: Diabetes assessment (risk factor for disc herniation, infection, neuropathy); post-operative wound healing
If imaging suggests neoplastic etiology rather than disc herniation
Multiple myeloma presenting as cauda equina compression
Immunocompromised → infection risk; primary CNS lymphoma differential
Pre-existing UTI; post-catheterization planning; differentiate neurogenic bladder from UTI
Extended Workup.target: Negative; if positive → treat but continue CES workup

Extended Workup.rationale: KEY DIAGNOSTIC TEST: bladder retention is hallmark of CES; PVR >200 mL is highly concerning; >500 mL strongly suggestive of neurogenic retention
Extended Workup.target: PVR <100 mL (normal); PVR >200 mL → significant retention; >500 mL → almost certainly neurogenic

Rare/Specialized.item: CSF analysis (only at surgery or LP if needed)
Rare/Specialized.rationale: If inflammatory/infectious etiology suspected (GBS affecting cauda equina = rare); leptomeningeal carcinomatosis
Rare/Specialized.target: Normal; elevated protein → GBS, tumor; malignant cells → leptomeningeal disease

Rare/Specialized.rationale: Atypical CES without structural cause; paraneoplastic cauda equina neuritis (anti-CRMP5/CV2, anti-amphiphysin)
GBS variant affecting cauda equina roots (rare); if imaging shows nerve root enhancement without structural compression
Rare/Specialized.target: Negative; positive → GBS/CIDP affecting cauda equina

Rare/Specialized.rationale: If conus medullaris lesion rather than cauda equina compression; NMOSD can affect conus
Neurosarcoidosis affecting cauda equina (nerve root inflammation/enhancement without structural lesion); elevated ACE
Rare/Specialized.target: Normal ACE; chest CT: no hilar lymphadenopathy; if positive → neurosarcoidosis

Rare/Specialized.rationale: Chronic or atypical CES; differentiate from peripheral neuropathy, plexopathy; establish nerve root involvement pattern; prognostic (denervation = poor recovery)
Rare/Specialized.target: Abnormal: acute denervation (fibrillations, positive sharp waves) in L4-S4 myotomes bilaterally; absent H-reflex bilaterally; abnormal pudendal nerve conduction

Lumbar Puncture.timing: LP is NOT required for diagnosis of typical CES (disc herniation, tumor, abscess seen on MRI); ONLY if inflammatory/infectious etiology without clear structural cause; OR CT myelogram if MRI impossible
Lumbar Puncture.target: CSF protein elevation (GBS, tumor); pleocytosis (infection, inflammation); malignant cells (leptomeningeal disease); albuminocytologic dissociation (GBS)
Lumbar Puncture.contraindications: Do NOT perform LP if large disc herniation compressing cauda equina (could theoretically worsen by altering pressure dynamics — proceed to surgery instead); coagulopathy; abscess at LP site

Essential/First-line.timing: **Within 4 hours of ED arrival — SURGICAL EMERGENCY; ideally within 1 hour**; extends to thoracolumbar junction (T10-sacrum) to include conus medullaris
Essential/First-line.target: Large disc herniation (most common — 45% of CES cases) compressing cauda equina; canal compromise; level of compression; number of roots compressed; disc fragment migration; tumor, abscess, or hematoma as alternative cause; conus medullaris location and signal
Essential/First-line.contraindications: MRI-incompatible implants; severe claustrophobia (sedate — do NOT delay MRI for anxiety); GFR <30 for contrast (but contrast NOT required for disc herniation diagnosis — obtain non-contrast first)

Essential/First-line.timing: Add contrast if: suspected abscess, tumor, or inflammatory etiology; ring-enhancing epidural collection = abscess; homogeneous enhancement = tumor; nerve root enhancement = inflammatory/neoplastic
Essential/First-line.target: Epidural abscess (ring enhancement, restricted diffusion); tumor (enhancing mass); nerve root enhancement (inflammatory, leptomeningeal disease); distinguish from disc herniation (which does NOT enhance)
Essential/First-line.contraindications: GFR <30 (gadolinium risk — benefit outweighs risk in emergency); gadolinium allergy (premedicate)

Essential/First-line.timing: **Before MRI if possible — critical triage tool**; have patient attempt to void → immediate bladder ultrasound for PVR
Essential/First-line.target: PVR >200 mL = significant retention → HIGH probability of CES; PVR >500 mL = almost certain neurogenic retention; normal PVR does NOT exclude early/incomplete CES

Essential/First-line.timing: While awaiting MRI; identifies vertebral collapse, spondylolisthesis, fracture, alignment; limited value but rapid triage tool
Essential/First-line.target: Disc space narrowing; spondylolisthesis; fracture; alignment abnormality; NOTE: X-rays CANNOT diagnose disc herniation — MRI is required

Extended.timing: If MRI not available or contraindicated; inferior to MRI for soft tissue but shows bone and canal narrowing; CT myelogram if MRI impossible
Extended.target: Disc herniation (seen as soft tissue density in canal); bone fragments; canal diameter; fracture; spondylolisthesis
Extended.contraindications: CT alone has limited sensitivity for disc herniation vs. MRI; myelogram adds invasive risk

Extended.timing: If MRI absolutely contraindicated (implant); intrathecal contrast via LP → CT; demonstrates level of block and root compression
Extended.target: Complete or partial block; compressed cauda equina roots; level and extent of compression; may miss small free fragments
Extended.contraindications: LP contraindicated if abscess suspected at LP site; coagulopathy; rare but important if MRI impossible

Extended.timing: If etiology unclear; evaluate for additional levels of disease; concurrent cord compression; tumor staging; multilevel disc disease
Extended.target: Additional sites of compression; intramedullary lesion (conus); multifocal disease

Extended.timing: Post-acute phase; quantify bladder dysfunction; detrusor areflexia (CES pattern); plan long-term bladder management
Extended.target: Detrusor areflexia (areflexic bladder) = cauda equina denervation; decreased bladder sensation; increased capacity; poor emptying
Extended.contraindications: Acute UTI; recent surgery (timing per surgeon)

Extended.timing: Quantify sphincter dysfunction; prognostic for recovery; pudendal nerve conduction
Extended.target: Reduced anal sphincter pressures; denervated pudendal nerve
Extended.contraindications: Patient tolerance; acute phase may not be appropriate

Extended.timing: 2-3 weeks post-onset (acute denervation takes 2-3 weeks to appear on EMG); prognosis; differentiate from peripheral neuropathy or plexopathy
Extended.target: Bilateral L4-S4 denervation; reduced CMAP amplitudes in bilateral L5/S1 distribution; absent H-reflexes bilaterally; bilateral pudendal neuropathy
Extended.contraindications: Too early in acute phase (<2 weeks = may be false negative for denervation); patient tolerance

Rare/Specialized.timing: If vascular malformation suspected (spinal dural AV fistula causing venous hypertension → CES symptoms); progressive myelopathy/CES with dilated serpiginous vessels on MRI
Rare/Specialized.target: Spinal AV fistula; AVM; arteriovenous malformation feeding vessels

Rare/Specialized.timing: Definitive diagnosis and treatment of spinal dural AV fistula; also pre-operative embolization for vascular tumors
If malignancy causing CES — staging; unknown primary identification
Formal bladder function assessment; post-decompression recovery monitoring; long-term bladder management planning
Rare/Specialized.target: Bladder compliance; detrusor function; capacity; sensation thresholds

dosing.instructions: **THIS IS A SURGICAL EMERGENCY — TIME IS NERVE**; Emergent neurosurgery/spine surgery consultation; posterior lumbar laminectomy with discectomy (most common procedure); **Timing:** Within 24h of symptom onset — ideally within 24h but outcome improves the sooner surgery is performed; <24h clearly better than >48h; some evidence supports <12h for best outcomes; **Complete CES (CES-R with retention):** Truly emergent — surgery as soon as possible (within hours); **Incomplete CES (CES-I):** Urgent — surgery within 24h; risk of progressing to complete

Acute/Emergent Treatment.monitoring: Ahn et al. (2000): Decompression <48h = significantly better outcomes for bladder recovery (70% vs. 30%); Todd (2005) meta-analysis: Earlier surgery = better outcomes, but exact time threshold debated; DeBois et al. (2019): <24h optimal, <48h acceptable; Srikandarajah et al. (2020): Urgent surgery (<24h) associated with better functional outcomes

dosing.instructions: **Bladder scan (PVR) STAT on arrival** — do NOT wait for MRI; if PVR >200 mL → Foley catheter placement; if PVR >500 mL → Foley + strict I&O monitoring; avoid overdistension (>600 mL causes detrusor damage — may become irreversible); document voiding pattern; post-operative: trial of void at 24-48h with PVR checks; CIC (clean intermittent catheterization) teaching if retention persists

Acute/Emergent Treatment.monitoring: Bladder overdistension causes detrusor muscle damage → irreversible areflexic bladder; early catheterization prevents secondary damage; bladder recovery is the MOST SENSITIVE indicator of CES recovery and the MOST COMMON persistent deficit

dosing.instructions: Back pain and radicular pain often severe; acetaminophen 650-1000 mg q6h (scheduled) + opioids (morphine 2-4 mg IV q3h PRN or hydromorphone 0.5-1 mg IV q3h PRN); NSAIDs: ketorolac 15-30 mg IV q6h (short-term, if no surgical contraindication and normal renal function — pre-op use is surgeon-dependent); neuropathic: gabapentin 300 mg TID (start if radicular pain prominent); avoid excessive sedation that obscures neurologic exam

Acute/Emergent Treatment.monitoring: Adequate analgesia essential for patient assessment and MRI tolerance; balance with need for neurologic monitoring

dosing.instructions: **Disc herniation CES:** Steroids NOT routinely indicated (no evidence of benefit; some centers use short course); **Tumor-related CES:** Dexamethasone 10 mg IV bolus → 4 mg q6h (same as MSCC protocol); **Abscess-related CES:** Dexamethasone controversial (may impair immune response) — use only if severe edema with rapid neurologic decline

Acute/Emergent Treatment.monitoring: No RCT evidence supporting steroids for disc-related CES; tumor CES: Sorensen et al. (1994) supports steroids; abscess: prioritize antibiotics + surgical drainage

dosing.instructions: **Epidural abscess causing CES:** Empiric: Vancomycin 25-30 mg/kg IV load + ceftriaxone 2g IV q12h (or cefepime 2g IV q8h); adjust to culture/sensitivity; MRSA coverage essential; **Duration:** Typically 6-8 weeks IV antibiotics for epidural abscess; **Timing:** Start AFTER blood cultures drawn but do NOT delay if patient is deteriorating

Acute/Emergent Treatment.monitoring: S. aureus (including MRSA) is most common organism in epidural abscess (60-70%); gram-negative coverage for UTI/abdominal source; streptococci, anaerobes less common

dosing.instructions: SCDs immediately; pharmacologic prophylaxis: enoxaparin 40 mg SQ daily starting post-operatively (typically 12-24h after surgery per surgeon protocol); immobile CES patients at high VTE risk

Acute/Emergent Treatment.monitoring: Immobility + lower extremity weakness = high DVT risk; mechanical prophylaxis pre-operatively; early pharmacologic prophylaxis post-operatively

dosing.instructions: Assess rectal tone (digital rectal exam — absent/reduced in CES); bowel regimen: docusate 100 mg BID + senna 2 tabs HS; bisacodyl suppository daily if no BM in 48h; monitor for fecal incontinence vs. constipation (both occur in CES); opioid-related constipation compounds the issue

Acute/Emergent Treatment.monitoring: Bowel dysfunction common in CES; S2-S4 denervation affects external anal sphincter and rectal sensation; proactive management prevents complications

dosing.instructions: **Most common surgery:** Posterior approach; laminectomy at affected level(s); remove herniated disc fragment; decompress cauda equina; **Approach:** Midline; may require bilateral laminotomy or hemi-laminectomy for lateralized discs; large central herniations often require bilateral approach; **Key:** Ensure COMPLETE decompression — incomplete decompression leads to persistent deficit; intraoperative confirmation with direct visualization of free cauda equina nerve roots
dosing.orderSentence: **Lumbar laminectomy + discectomy (disc herniation CES)** - - - see dosing

Definitive/Targeted Treatment.monitoring: Gold standard for disc-related CES; no RCT comparing surgery vs. non-operative (would be unethical to randomize given natural history); observational data uniformly supports early surgical decompression

dosing.instructions: Minimally invasive approach; appropriate for contained disc herniations without significant canal stenosis; faster recovery; less tissue disruption; may not provide adequate decompression for massive central disc herniation

Definitive/Targeted Treatment.monitoring: Smaller incision, less muscle disruption; but surgeon must ensure adequate decompression — do NOT compromise canal visualization for a smaller incision in CES

dosing.instructions: Posterior approach; laminectomy; drain abscess; culture material; irrigate; leave wound open or with drain; may require multi-level decompression; **Combined with:** IV antibiotics 6-8 weeks; follow with serial MRI and inflammatory markers
dosing.orderSentence: **Surgical drainage + decompression (epidural abscess)** - IV - see dosing

Definitive/Targeted Treatment.monitoring: Epidural abscess with CES = surgical emergency; medical management alone (antibiotics without surgery) only if: no neurologic deficit AND very high surgical risk; most CES presentations require surgery

dosing.instructions: If tumor-related CES (e.g., schwannoma, ependymoma, metastasis); posterior decompression ± en bloc or piecemeal tumor resection; send pathology; may need subsequent radiation/chemotherapy

Definitive/Targeted Treatment.monitoring: Intradural-extramedullary tumors (schwannoma, meningioma, myxopapillary ependymoma) are potentially curable with complete resection; metastatic CES → decompression + radiation

dosing.instructions: Epidural hematoma causing CES (spontaneous on anticoagulation, post-procedural, or post-traumatic); emergent laminectomy with hematoma evacuation; reverse anticoagulation STAT

Definitive/Targeted Treatment.monitoring: Spontaneous spinal epidural hematoma: Groen & Ponssen (1990): better outcomes with surgery <12h of onset; anticoagulation reversal essential (4F-PCC for warfarin, idarucizumab for dabigatran, andexanet for Xa inhibitors)

dosing.instructions: **ONLY appropriate if:** (1) Imaging does NOT show significant structural compression, (2) Symptoms are improving spontaneously, (3) Patient refuses surgery (document informed refusal thoroughly), (4) Medically inoperable (extremely high surgical risk); **Requires:** Close monitoring with serial neuro exams q2-4h; repeat MRI if worsening; immediate surgery if any progression

Definitive/Targeted Treatment.monitoring: Non-operative management is NOT standard of care for CES with structural compression; delayed surgery has worse outcomes; informed consent must document risks of non-operative management (permanent bladder/bowel/sexual dysfunction, progressive weakness)

dosing.instructions: If bladder function does not recover by 48-72h post-surgery; teach patient CIC q4-6h; target PVR <100 mL before discontinuing CIC; may take weeks to months to recover

Adjunctive Treatment.monitoring: CIC is preferred over indwelling Foley for long-term bladder management (lower UTI risk); most patients can learn self-catheterization; bladder recovery may take 6-12 months

dosing.instructions: Gabapentin 300 mg PO TID → titrate to 600-900 mg TID over 1-2 weeks; OR pregabalin 75 mg BID → 150-300 mg BID; duloxetine 30 mg daily → 60 mg daily; amitriptyline 10-25 mg HS (caution: urinary retention may worsen); topical lidocaine 5% patches for localized radicular pain

Adjunctive Treatment.monitoring: Neuropathic pain (burning, tingling, electric shocks in perineum, legs) is common and debilitating after CES; may persist chronically; multimodal approach needed

dosing.instructions: PT evaluation within 24h post-operatively; early mobilization; lower extremity strengthening; gait training; core stabilization; progressive activity as tolerated; pelvic floor PT for bladder/bowel recovery

Adjunctive Treatment.monitoring: Early rehabilitation improves functional outcomes; pelvic floor rehabilitation is evidence-based for bladder/bowel recovery after CES

dosing.instructions: ADL assessment; adaptive equipment; if lower extremity weakness impairs function; bathroom modifications; return-to-work planning

Specialized pelvic floor PT; biofeedback for bladder and bowel retraining; Kegel exercises (if able); electrical stimulation of pelvic floor; sacral neuromodulation evaluation if persistent dysfunction >12 months

Adjunctive Treatment.monitoring: Evidence supports pelvic floor PT for bladder and bowel recovery after CES; biofeedback improves outcomes

dosing.instructions: CES has devastating psychosocial impact (sexual dysfunction, incontinence, chronic pain, disability in often-young patients); depression screening (PHQ-9); anxiety screening; sexual health counseling; support groups; consider psychiatry referral

Adjunctive Treatment.monitoring: Depression affects 30-60% of CES patients long-term; sexual dysfunction is profoundly distressing; early psychological intervention improves coping and recovery

dosing.instructions: Docusate 100 mg BID + senna 2 tabs HS; bisacodyl suppository PRN; digital stimulation for areflexic bowel; timed bowel program; fiber supplementation; adequate hydration

Adjunctive Treatment.monitoring: Neurogenic bowel management reduces complications (impaction, incontinence); establish routine bowel program early

dosing.orderSentence: Anticholinergics (oxybutynin, tolterodine — for urgency) - - - see dosing
Alpha-blockers (tamsulosin, silodosin) — without urologic guidance - - - see dosing

Medications to AVOID or Use with Caution.item: Epidural steroid injection (as treatment for CES)

dosing.orderSentence: Epidural steroid injection (as treatment for CES) - - - see dosing
Excessive IV fluids (post-operatively) - IV - see dosing

Referrals & Consults.item: Transfer to surgical center (if no spine surgeon)

differential.features: Upper motor neuron AND lower motor neuron signs; bilateral and symmetric; early bladder/bowel dysfunction; back pain less prominent than radicular pain; reflexes may be hyperactive (UMN) or absent (LMN); typically at T12-L2 level; more symmetric than CES
differential.tests: MRI: lesion at T12-L2 level (conus); cord signal change (T2 hyperintensity); CES lesion is below L1-L2 (cauda equina roots only); conus lesion → Babinski may be present (CES → absent or flexor)

differential.features: Neurogenic claudication (walking-induced symptoms relieved by sitting/flexion); chronic progressive course; bilateral leg pain/weakness with walking; no bladder/bowel dysfunction (unless severe CES from stenosis); intermittent symptoms
differential.tests: MRI: multilevel stenosis; trefoil canal shape; ligamentum flavum hypertrophy; NO acute disc herniation; symptoms are exercise-induced, not constant; PVR normal

differential.features: Unilateral radiculopathy; no bilateral symptoms; no saddle anesthesia; no bladder/bowel dysfunction; straight leg raise positive; single dermatomal pattern
differential.tests: MRI: lateral or posterolateral disc herniation compressing single root; NO cauda equina compression; normal PVR; normal rectal tone

differential.features: Fever (50-66%); IVDU, immunocompromised, recent procedure; rapidly progressive; ESR >20 (94% sensitivity); severe spinal tenderness; leukocytosis; can cause CES if lumbar location
differential.tests: MRI: ring-enhancing epidural collection with restricted diffusion; blood cultures positive (60%); ESR/CRP markedly elevated; clinical triad: back pain → radiculopathy → weakness (classic but only 10-15% present with full triad)

differential.features: Acute onset; anticoagulation or post-procedural (epidural injection, spinal surgery, LP); severe back pain → rapid progressive weakness; coagulopathy history
differential.tests: MRI: epidural collection with blood signal (T1 bright in subacute); coagulation studies abnormal; anticoagulation history; post-procedural temporal relationship

differential.features: Ascending symmetric weakness; areflexia; post-infectious (Campylobacter, CMV, EBV); sensory symptoms but often mild; facial weakness may be present; no saddle anesthesia typically; CSF: albuminocytologic dissociation
differential.tests: MRI spine: may show nerve root enhancement BUT no structural compression; CSF: elevated protein, normal cells; NCS: demyelinating pattern or AMAN pattern; anti-ganglioside antibodies

differential.features: Chronic course; distal > proximal; length-dependent pattern; diabetes, alcohol; stocking-glove distribution; gradual onset; reflexes may be reduced distally; NO saddle anesthesia; NO acute bladder retention
differential.tests: EMG/NCS: diffuse length-dependent neuropathy; MRI: no structural compression; HbA1c; B12; SPEP; gradual course distinguishes from acute CES

differential.features: Unilateral (usually); painful; diabetic amyotrophy; radiation-induced; tumor infiltration; asymmetric weakness/sensory loss in lumbosacral plexus distribution; typically NO bladder dysfunction (unless bilateral)
differential.tests: MRI pelvis: plexus enhancement or mass; EMG: plexus distribution denervation; CT abdomen/pelvis: retroperitoneal mass; HbA1c; typically unilateral

differential.features: Inconsistent exam findings; Hoover's sign positive; non-anatomical sensory pattern; normal imaging; normal PVR; no objective sphincter dysfunction; give-way weakness; history of psychological stressors
differential.tests: MRI: normal; PVR: normal; rectal tone: normal; neurophysiology: normal; psychiatric history; clinical inconsistency (e.g., inability to lift leg on command but normal gait observed); NOTE: FND is a diagnosis of exclusion in CES — always obtain MRI first

evidence.evidenceLevel: Systematic review: Decompression <48h of CES onset → 70% bladder recovery vs. 30% if >48h; motor outcomes also significantly better with early surgery
evidence.source: Established 48h as important threshold; but sooner is always better

evidence.evidenceLevel: 42 studies: Earlier decompression consistently associated with better outcomes across motor, bladder, and bowel domains; no clear cutoff but <24h is optimal
evidence.source: Confirmed urgency of CES surgical decompression; surgical timing is KEY modifiable factor

evidence.evidenceLevel: UK Cohort: Urgent surgery (<24h) vs. delayed (>24h): better bladder outcomes (OR 2.1) and motor outcomes (OR 1.6) with urgent surgery
evidence.source: Modern evidence supporting <24h surgical timing; NHS pathway development

evidence.evidenceLevel: Timing analysis: <12h, 12-24h, 24-48h, >48h: progressive decline in outcomes with each delay interval; <12h had best bladder recovery
evidence.source: Supports as-soon-as-possible approach; <12h may be ideal

evidence.evidenceLevel: CES-I vs. CES-R outcomes: CES-I (incomplete) with early surgery → 95% good bladder outcome; CES-R (retention) with early surgery → 53% good bladder outcome; CES-R with delayed surgery → 27% good outcome
evidence.source: Established CES-I vs. CES-R classification; demonstrated that retention onset is critical prognostic marker

evidence.evidenceLevel: Spinal epidural hematoma: better outcomes with surgery <12h of onset; anticoagulation most common cause
evidence.source: Established surgical urgency for hematoma-related CES

evidence.evidenceLevel: Classic paper on CES natural history: untreated CES from disc herniation → permanent bladder dysfunction in >90%, persistent weakness in >70%, chronic pain in >80%
evidence.source: Established that CES without surgical treatment leads to devastating permanent deficits

evidence.evidenceLevel: Medicolegal analysis: CES is the most litigated condition in spinal surgery; delayed diagnosis is the most common reason for successful claims; failure to perform timely MRI and delayed surgery are key factors
evidence.source: Documentation of timeline is CRITICAL; standardized CES pathways reduce medicolegal risk

evidence.evidenceLevel: Definition
evidence.source: Key Features

evidence.evidenceLevel: Bilateral radiculopathy/symptoms WITHOUT bladder dysfunction
evidence.source: Bilateral leg pain/weakness; bilateral sensory changes; NO urinary symptoms; normal PVR

evidence.evidenceLevel: Altered urinary function WITHOUT retention
evidence.source: Difficulty initiating stream; reduced sensation of voiding; urgency; partial retention (PVR 200-500 mL); reduced but present perineal sensation; reduced anal tone

evidence.evidenceLevel: Painless urinary retention WITH overflow incontinence
evidence.source: Painless retention (PVR >500 mL); overflow incontinence; absent perineal sensation; absent anal tone; often absent bulbocavernosus reflex

monitoring.item: Neurologic examination (lower extremity strength, sensation, reflexes)
monitoring.action: Pre-op worsening: escalate surgical urgency; post-op worsening: STAT MRI (hematoma, residual compression, re-herniation)

monitoring.frequency: q4h (at minimum with each neuro check)
Continuous monitoring via Foley with hourly I&O pre/post-op; Trial of void at 24-48h post-op with PVR check
monitoring.target: PVR <100 mL to discontinue catheter; voiding spontaneously
monitoring.action: PVR >200 mL after trial of void → replace Foley; begin CIC teaching; urology consult
Escalate analgesics; add neuropathic agents; new/worsening pain post-op → concern for hematoma/complication
Wound complication → surgical team notification; drain output monitoring
Bowel regimen intensification; abdominal X-ray if distended; rectal exam
Fever: wound infection, UTI (Foley-associated), DVT, abscess; cultures and imaging as indicated
Bilateral lower extremity duplex US if symptoms; therapeutic anticoagulation if confirmed

disposition.criteria: Post-operative monitoring (surgeon-dependent — many post-laminectomies go to floor); bilateral lower extremity paralysis with hemodynamic concerns; epidural abscess with sepsis; significant comorbidities affecting anesthetic recovery; autonomic dysfunction

ALL CES patients require admission; pre-operative CES awaiting surgical decompression; post-operative monitoring; pain management; bladder/bowel monitoring; PT/OT initiation; epidural abscess requiring IV antibiotics

CES is NEVER an observation diagnosis — all suspected CES patients require emergent MRI and admission for surgical evaluation; even if MRI is negative for structural compression, admission for monitoring is prudent if clinical suspicion is high
